docs.lead_paragraph: State lawmakers are considering a bill that would make New Jersey the first state in the nation to require public schools to teach breast self-examination in health education classes. The bill passed the state Senate earlier this month and goes on to the Assembly Education Committee for consideration.
docs.abstract: New Jersey lawmakers consider bill to require public schools to teach breast self-examination in health education classes; Assembly approves measure to require insurance companies to notify applicant who tests positive for life-threatening communicable disease such as AIDS (New Jersey Briefs) (S)
docs.snippet: State lawmakers are considering a bill that would make New Jersey the first state in the nation to require public schools to teach breast self-examination in health education classes.    The bill passed the state Senate earlier this month and goes on...
docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: ALL eyes are on the state Assembly in the expectation that it will pull a legislative rabbit out of its hat and give New Jersey drivers a reduction of at least 10 percent in their annual auto insurance premiums -- infamously the highest in the nation -- without reducing the level of coverage. While it is probably unwise for us to hold our breath on that one, drivers here should take note of two little-known ways to reduce their premiums, without affecting coverage, that are already in place and just waiting for us to take advantage of them.
docs.abstract: Lauren Otis comment suggests New Jerseyans can look for relief from huge auto insurance premiums through group coverage or by designating health insurers as first payer under auto policies, if that is permitted (S)
